content.statement: aaa-001-definition is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aaa that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aaa-001-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aaa-001-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aaa-001-definition.

definitions_glossary.aneurysm: Permanent, localized arterial dilation involving all wall layers, >50% normal diameter
definitions_glossary.true_aneurysm: Dilation involving all three arterial wall layers (intima, media, adventitia)
definitions_glossary.pseudoaneurysm: Contained rupture with blood contained by surrounding tissue, not all wall layers
definitions_glossary.aorta: The main artery carrying blood from the heart to the body
definitions_glossary.ectasia: Arterial dilation less than 50% above normal, typically 2.5-3.0 cm for infrarenal aorta

epidemiology.prevalence: 4-8% in men over 65, 0.5-1.5% in women over 65

natural_history.growth_rate: Average 2-3 mm per year, accelerates with larger diameter

definition.@value: Permanent localized dilation of the abdominal aorta to diameter ≥3.0 cm or >50% larger than normal, involving all three arterial wall layers

prerequisites.title: Arterial System
prerequisites.reason: AAA occurs in the arterial system

prerequisites.title: Atherosclerosis
prerequisites.reason: Atherosclerosis is a major risk factor for AAA

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define abdominal aortic aneurysm using standard criteria
Distinguish true aneurysm from pseudoaneurysm and ectasia
Identify the most common anatomic location for AAA
Understand the significance of the 3.0 cm threshold
common_errors: Not recognizing that most AAAs are asymptomatic
Using diameter alone without considering growth rate
Applying male size thresholds to female patients
clinical_pearls: Normal infrarenal aortic diameter: ~2.0 cm in men, ~1.7 cm in women
AAA is often an incidental finding on imaging for other conditions
Presence of AAA strongly correlates with other aneurysms (popliteal, iliac)
